title-group.article-title: Important Nonparental Adults as an Academic Resource for Youth

article-meta.aff: 1The University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand

author-notes.corresp: Susan P. Farruggia, The University of Auckland, Faculty of Education, School of Teaching, Learning and Development, Private Bag 92601, Auckland, New Zealand. Email: s.farruggia@auckland.ac.nz

abstract.p: This study examined the associations between various sources of social support and academic achievement. Participants were 313 ethnically diverse students attending a low-income intermediate school in New Zealand (mean age = 11.96 years). They reported on the presence and nature of a relationship with a very important nonparental adult in their lives (VIP), and on parent, peer, and VIP warmth and acceptance. Indicators of academic achievement (standardized tests) were also gathered from the school. Results showed that 62% of the youth reported the presence of at least one VIP in their lives, and there was a significant, positive correlation between VIP presence and the majority of academic achievement variables. VIP warmth was uniquely associated with all achievement variables, while parent and peer warmth were nonsignificant in the presence of VIP warmth. The results indicate that VIPs are an important resource for youth who are at risk of low achievement.

body.p: Evidence of academic underachievement of some student groups has been well documented in many countries. For instance, in the United States, African American and Latino adolescents typically underperform in comparison to their European and Asian counterparts (e.g., Aud et al., 2011; Steinberg, Dornbusch, & Brown, 1992). Government statistics in New Zealand (NZ) indicate Māori (indigenous people of New Zealand) and Pasifika (Pacific Island) youth tend to underperform academically compared to New Zealand (NZ) European- and Asian-background peers (Ministry of Māori Affairs/Te Puni Kokiri, 2000; Ministry of Pacific Island Affairs, 2003). Compared to Asian and NZ European students, a lower percentage of Māori and Pasifika youth reach proficiency levels in reading, math, and science at all levels of high school (Ministry of Education, 2006). Furthermore, data from 1993 to 2007 showed that a much higher percentage of Māori and Pasifika students, compared to NZ European and Asian students, left formal schooling with little or no formal qualification, and this trend was particularly profound for low socioeconomic status (SES) Māori and Pasifika students (Education Counts, 2007).

The underachievement of particular student groups has drawn much attention in an attempt to explain and change the apparent patterns. Coleman’s (1987) concept of social capital provides the framework for examining this issue. Social capital, as it relates to childrearing, refers to the “norms, the social networks, and the relationships between adults and children that are of value for the child’s growing up. Social capital exists within the family, but also outside the family, in the community” (p. 36). Coleman suggested that children have experienced a loss of social capital due to parents working outside of the home resulting in schools and other institutions becoming more responsible for the socialization of children. Furthermore, Coleman contended that the erosion of social capital has led to a decline in academic achievement. The costs of the change in societal structures and the resulting loss of social capital will be “borne disproportionately by the disadvantaged of the next generation—for the loss of social capital in the community hurts most the children with least human and social capital in their families” (p. 37).

Poverty, as well as other factors such as low parent education and language proficiency, have been noted as possible risk factors for underachievement (Bempechat & Ginsburg, 1989; Muller, Stage, & Kinzie, 2001; Pallas, Natriello, & McDill, 1989; Sirin, 2005). Indeed, family income appears to moderate other risk factors for lower achievement, such as single parenting (Milne, Myers, Rosenthal, & Ginsberg, 1986). Interestingly, language proficiency appears to be uniquely associated with achievement as compared with SES (Santiago, Lukas, Joaristi, Lizasoain, & Moyano, 2008). In New Zealand, both Māori and Pasifika youth are more likely to be affected by poverty compared to other groups, which is associated with underachievement (Biddulph, Biddulph, & Biddulph, 2003; Gilbert, 2005).

It has been suggested that within the New Zealand cultural context, Anglo Saxon dominance combined with experiences of discrimination and prejudice have historically delegitimized many of the values that define Māori and Pasifika culture and identity (e.g., Sachdev, 1990). This loss of identity has been attributed to Māori (Bishop, Berryman, Cavanagh, & Teddy, 2007; Durie, 2005) and Pasifika (Mila-Schaaf & Robinson, 2010) underachievement. Within the United States, it is also suggested that attitudes toward school and academic motivation are shaped by cultural mistrust placing minority groups in a position of academic disadvantage (Ogbu, 1982, 1997). Furthermore, as noted by Wilson (1996), an individual’s “skills, habits and styles are often shaped by the frequency at which they are found in their own community” (p. 72). As many minority youth attend low-income schools and live in the poorest communities, it is likely that access to these tools of success as well as community social capital may be diminished.

In line with Coleman’s notion of social capital, research has long indicated the importance of social relationships on adolescent adjustment and, in particular, achievement (e.g., Demaray & Malecki, 2002; Malecki & Elliott, 1999). Strong, positive associations have been consistently found between both parental and peer relationships with academic achievement. Boon (2007) examined 879 Grade 8 to 10 Australian students’ grades in relation to parenting style. Participants’ report of higher levels of authoritative parenting, indicated by higher parental monitoring and warmth, predicted greater academic achievement by way of mastery of goals and self-efficacy. Furthermore, a meta-analysis conducted by Hill and Tyson (2009) on over 50 studies showed a positive association between parental involvement and early adolescent academic achievement.

Research has also indicated that peer support can have a positive effect on school success. Kurdek, Fine, and Sinclair (1995) found that sixth-grade students’ grade point average (GPA) was positively associated with peer norms supporting academic excellence, although this was only the case when there was higher family acceptance. A study of Mexican American youth by Alva (1991) revealed that participants’ report of friends’ academic support and academic attitudes was a significant discriminator between participants with higher and lower grades. Indeed, relationships with peers have been found to be associated with achievement and school engagement (Ream & Rumberger, 2008; Troop-Gordon, Visconti, & Kuntz, 2011; Veronneau & Dishion, 2011). In one study in New Zealand, using older peer mentors was more effective in supporting the transition to secondary school for Māori and Pasifika youth as compared to the NZ European counterparts (Noonan, Bullen, & Farruggia, in press), highlighting the importance of examining the cultural context of support.

Coleman (1987) also suggested that social capital can occur outside of the family in the community and “exists in the interests, even the intrusiveness, of one adult in the activities of someone else’s child” (p. 36). These interests can take a variety of forms, such as enforcing norms of the parents or community, listening to problems, and working with youth groups. A growing body of research has examined the importance of nonparental adults in the lives of young people. One such group is that of VIPs, or very important nonparental adults (VIPs), who are people who adolescents nominate who are at least 19 years old, are a significant influence, and can be counted on in a time of need (Greenberger, Chen, & Beam, 1998). VIPs are distinguished from extended family members (although there is overlap in these two groups) as the teens select their VIPs and do not select their extended family members. Furthermore, it is inherent to the definition that VIPs are available to the young people, but this is not the case for extended family.

Research has demonstrated, generally speaking, that VIPs are equally likely to be family members as not. For instance, Greenberger and colleagues (1998) found that 52% of the women and 48% of the men in their study had a kin VIP. Similarly, DuBois and Silverthorn (2005) found that only 40% of their sample of natural mentors was family members. Interestingly, Chen, Greenberger, Farruggia, Bush, and Dong (2003) found that Chinese adolescents were equally likely to select familial VIPs as were U.S. adolescents, whereas, within the United States, European American youth were less likely to select a kin VIP as compared to Latino, Asian, and African American adolescents (Chang, Greenberger, Chen, Heckhausen, & Farruggia, 2010). As the nature of the adolescent-VIP relationship is relatively unexamined, including ethnic variations in those relationships, further investigation is warranted.

Of late, research has pointed to an association between the presence and characteristics of VIPs and academic performance among older adolescents in their final year of high school and in the transition to college/work (Chang et al., 2010). Chang and colleagues found that youth with a VIP reported higher grades than those without a VIP, although both groups had similar educational expectations. Furthermore, they also found a positive association between VIP educational background and youths’ self-reported grades. Using a nationally representative sample, Erickson and colleagues found that having a natural mentor was associated with both greater academic achievement as indicated by school-reported GPA and increased educational attainment, particularly when the mentor was a teacher (Erickson, McDonald, & Elder, 2009). Among a high-risk sample, Farruggia’s (2006) study of older adolescents in foster care as they transitioned to adulthood found that good relationships with VIPs during the postemancipation period were associated with self-reported postemancipation educational success.

Research on adolescent development clearly demonstrates having VIPs in the youths’ lives is normative and contributes to well-being (Beam, Chen, & Greenberger, 2002; Blyth, Hill, & Thiel, 1982; Werner & Smith, 1982). Furthermore, unlike formal mentoring relationships, these relationships did not typically develop as the result of difficulties in the youths’ lives (Beam et al., 2002). Blyth and colleagues found that the majority of adolescents reported having at least one important nonrelated adult and one important adult extended family member. Others have indicted natural mentor presence can make a positive difference in the lives of adolescents (e.g., DuBois & Silverthorn, 2005). In Werner and Smith’s longitudinal study of children at high risk, participants who became well-adjusted adults, despite experiencing early family instability and poverty, had an important adult in their lives. Nonparental adults have further been shown to have a positive influence in assisting adolescents to focus on a brighter future and overcome adversity (Garmezy, 1991; Rhodes, Spencer, Keller, & Liang, 2006; Werner & Smith, 1982). The presence of a nonparental important adult has also been linked with reduced anxiety (Rhodes, Contreras, & Mangelsdorf, 1994) and with better anger regulation (Spencer, 2006). Interestingly, young people with fewer social resources appear to benefit the most with having a natural mentor (Erickson et al., 2009).

Research indicates not only is the presence of the VIP important but also the quality of the adolescent-VIP relationship (Greenberger et al., 1998). Greenberger and colleagues demonstrated that the perceived mood and positive behavior of the VIP were predictive of adolescent depressive symptomatology. VIP warmth was marginally associated with depressive symptomatology for girls, but not for boys. VIPs’ perceived sanctions of and lack of involvement in health-compromising behaviors have also been reported to protect adolescents against problem behavior (Beam et al., 2002; Farruggia & Sorkin, 2009). VIPs have been identified as being of great importance to youth, particularly VIPs with whom the adolescent has frequent contact (Beam et al., 2002), although associations between levels of contact with the VIP and the level of importance of the VIP and adolescent adjustment have largely been unexamined but is established in the formal mentoring literature (e.g., DuBois & Neville, 1997). This high-quality VIP-adolescent relationship may be particularly important in the light of Coleman’s (1987) work on social capital. The disadvantage resulting from the erosion of social capital in the home, which can have negative effects on school retention and success, may be protected against through the support of a VIP. Indeed, research has found that natural mentors are often role models (e.g., Klaw, Rhodes, & Fitzgerald, 2003) and provide guidance (Zimmerman, Bingenheimer, & Behrendt, 2005), and their relationships often gradually develop (Beam et al., 2002).

Given the positive associations between VIP presence and qualities and adolescent well-being, examining the relationship between VIPs and academic achievements remains an important area of study. Importantly, VIPs have previously been reported by adolescents as being more warm and accepting than parents and peers (Beam et al., 2002; Chen et al., 2003; Farruggia, Greenberger, Chen, & Heckhausen, 2006). The current study tests Coleman’s suggestion that nonparental adults can provide the needed support to be successful in school. It builds upon prior research by examining the unique contribution of VIP presence, including frequency of contact, importance, and warmth, to academic achievement among young New Zealand adolescents. Furthermore, it expands the research in this area by examining the influence of VIPs on unique cultural groups. New Zealand culture differs from that of the United States, where much of the research on VIPs and natural mentors has been conducted. For instance, Māori culture has a greater societal prominence as compared to indigenous peoples in the United States (e.g., New Zealand is considered a bicultural country with aspects of Māori culture integrated in daily life). For another example, other New Zealand ethnic minority groups typically have Pacific Island and Asian backgrounds as opposed to Latino or African backgrounds that are more common in the United States. New Zealand in general, and Māori and Pasifika peoples in particular, have a more collectivist orientation as compared to the United States. Therefore, this study aims to test the following hypotheses:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1 (H1): Most youth will have a VIP and the VIPs will likely be family members.
Hypothesis 2 (H2): Youth will report greater levels of warmth from VIPs compared to parents or peers.

Hypothesis 3 (H3): VIP presence, VIP warmth, as well as peer warmth and parental warmth, frequency of contact with VIP, and importance of VIP, will make unique contributions to a youth’s academic achievement.

Hypothesis 4 (H4): The associations between VIP warmth, VIP presence, VIP importance, and frequency of contact with VIP with achievement will be greater for Māori and Pasifika youth compared to others and will be greater for kin VIPs compared to non-kin VIPs.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p:
Participants were 313 young adolescents (50% female) enrolled at an intermediate school (similar to junior high school) in a low-income area in Auckland, New Zealand. As determined by the Ministry of Education, the school had a decile 3 ranking. (Decile ratings range from 1 to 10 with lower numbers reflecting lower SES of the students enrolled in the school; decile 1 to 3 schools are considered “low” decile.) The youth were 11- to 13-year-olds (
X ¯
= 11.96, SD = 0.75) and the majority (85%) had been born in New Zealand. The ethnic makeup of the sample, reflecting the diversity of the area, was 30% Māori (indigenous people of New Zealand), 30% New Zealand European, 23% Pasifika (12% Samoan, 5% Cook Islander, 3% Tongan, 4% other Pacific Islander), 7% East/Southeast Asian, 7% Indian (including Fijian Indian), and 3% Other (dual ethnicity). Half of the students (50%) reported living with both parents and the remaining lived in a variety of household compositions: parents and other relations (13%), mother only (10%), mother and stepfather/partner (8%), mother and other relative (7%), or other (12%). Most students reported that at least one parent had completed high school (57%), with approximately one third having completed some tertiary education. The majority of parents, 70% of mothers and 87% of fathers, worked outside the home.

Of the 429 students enrolled in the school, 391 were present in their classrooms during the time of administration. Of those, 317 students (81%) had parental consent and participated in the study, which reflected 74% of the youth enrolled in the school. Four surveys were not included in the final sample due to inconsistent responses.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Once consent was obtained from the school principal, announcements were made about the study to the students in individual classrooms, while distributing parent information sheets and consent forms. A week later, youth were consented and youth questionnaires were administered by research staff to all students who had parental consent. All students who completed questionnaires went into a draw to win one of four $50 shopping mall gift certificates.
School records, including standardized test scores of academic achievement, were obtained from the school at the end of the school year. For seven students, only partial records were provided.

sec.title: Demographics
sec.p: Participants provided demographic information, including gender (1 = female, 2 = male), age, ethnicity, and parental education. For correlation and regression analyses, ethnicity was recoded 0 = Māori and/or Pasifika and 1 = NZ European, Asian, and Indian. Two youth did not fit this grouping and their data were coded as system missing. This recode was conducted so that variation due to ethnicity could be controlled for, as previous research has demonstrated that Māori and Pasifika youth tend to underperform academically. For parental education, participants indicated the highest level of education attained as follows: 1 = primary school, 2 = intermediate school, 3 = secondary school, 4 = university degree or diploma, and 5 = masters degree or beyond. The highest level of education for either parent was accepted.

sec.title: VIP
sec.p: Participants were also asked to indicate whether they had an important adult in their lives who was not their parent, who has had a significant influence on them, and whom they felt they could count on in times of need, and if yes, how many. They then answered a series of questions about their most important VIP, including age, gender, ethnicity, level of education (1 = did not complete high school, 2 = completed high school, 3 = completed tertiary school), overall importance of VIP (1 = important, 2 = very important, 3 = truly key), frequency of contact (seeing or talking) with VIP (1 = a few times a year, 2 = once of twice a month, 3 = once or twice a week, 4 = nearly everyday), and relationship to them (e.g., grandparent, coach).

sec.title: Warmth of relationships
sec.p: Participants also reported on warmth and understanding of parents, peers, and VIPs. Warmth and understanding was measured using adaptations of the Parental, Peer and VIP Warmth and Acceptance Scales (Greenberger et al., 1998), which assess the emotional quality of a relationship. The original scales had 11 items that made up one factor with the same structure across a variety of ethic groups (Chen, Farruggia, Greenberger, & Powers, 2002). The modified scales (reduced by three items each) have been found to be reliable (Farruggia et al., 2006). Each scale used a 4-point Likert-type response option ranging from 1 = disagree to 4 = agree. A sample item included, “I know that they will ‘be there’ for me if I need them.” The scales had acceptable reliability for all groups of people (parents α = .75, peers α = .78, VIP α = .74).

sec.title: Academic achievement
sec.p: Achievement in numeracy and literacy was assessed using three national standardized tests, including the following:

asTTle (Assessment Tools for Teaching and Learning) is an assessment tool that was developed specifically for the New Zealand Ministry of Education to assess achievement in literacy and numeracy (Assessment Tools for Teaching and Learning, 2003). Numeracy scores in this study included algebra addition and subtraction, algebra multiplication and division, geometry, statistics, and overall numeracy. Scores for subscales are reported on a scale from 1 to 5, with higher scores indicating relatively greater achievement. The overall score is generated using item response theory, again with higher scores indicating relatively greater achievement.

PAT (Progressive Achievement Tests) is a test primarily designed to help classroom teachers determine achievement levels of their students in reading comprehension and reading vocabulary (Darr, McDowall, Ferral, Twist, & Watson, 2008). This study used reading comprehension and vocabulary subtests. Scores are percentiles with higher numbers indicating relatively higher achievement.

STAR (Supplementary Test of Achievement in Reading) was used to provide a supplementary assessment in reading (Elley, 2001). The current study used the word recognition, sentence comprehension, paragraph comprehension, vocabulary, language, and writing subtests. Total scores are converted to stanines ranging from 1 to 9 (9 reflecting over 96% correct and 1 reflecting less than 4% correct) and indicate how well each pupil achieved on the test in relation to others of their age group (Elley, 2001). In addition, a total overall score was used, which was the sum of all of the subscales.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Data were screened for outliers, skewness, and patterns of missing data. Significant results of these preliminary analyses are reported in the descriptions of the variables. For VIP variables, an outlier was detected for number of VIPs as a participant reported having 40 VIPs. As this was well beyond 3 standard deviations (3.25) above the mean (1.89), the value was changed to the next largest value of 13, which was within one of the cutoff. Most participants reported having at least one VIP (62%), with 1.80 VIPs (SD = 2.47) on average. The highest level of VIP education was 11% did not complete high school, 45% completed high school, and 44% completed tertiary study. Most VIPs were family members (79%) and were the same ethnicity (76%) as the youth. See Table 1 for a complete list of VIP characteristics.

caption.p: VIP (Very Important Nonparental Adult) Characteristics and Qualities.

tr.td: VIP ethnicity is same as youth
Overall importance of VIP to participant
How often participant sees or talks to VIP

sec.p:
Participants reported high levels of warmth from their parents (
X ¯
= 3.37, SD = 0.59), peers (
X ¯
= 3.23, SD = 0.60), and VIPs (
X ¯
= 3.60, SD = 0.47). Not unexpectedly, therefore, VIP warmth, parent warmth, and peer warmth all were negatively skewed. In addition, VIP warmth was significantly higher than parental warmth, t(1) = 3.61, p < .001, and peer warmth, t(1) = 6.54, p < .001, and parental warmth was significantly higher than peer warmth, t(1) = 3.39, p < .01. Interestingly, correlational analyses revealed that associations among these three were low to moderate, although all statistically significant (parents/VIPs, r = .15, p < .05; peers/VIPs, r = .28, p < .001; parents/peers, r = .30, p < .001).

As expected for recruiting from the entire school, there was a wide range of achievement as indicated by scores on the various standardized tests (Table 2). Furthermore, PAT vocabulary had a positive skew, whereas many of the STAR scores, including word recognition, paragraph comprehension, vocabulary, language, writing, and the overall score had a negative skew. None of the asTTle scores were skewed.

fn.p: Note: N = 313; STAR = Supplementary Test of Achievement in Reading; Progressive Achievement Tests; asTTle = Assessment Tools for Teaching and Learning.

fn.label: f
fn.p: n = 209 as not all students were given this subtest.

fn.label: g
fn.p: Overall score calculated using Item Response Theory

sec.p: Correlations among standardized test scores and the youth’s gender and ethnicity, VIP presence, overall importance of VIP, frequency of contact with VIP, VIP education, VIP warmth, peer warmth, parental warmth, and parental education are presented in Table 3. Although gender and ethnicity are categorical, they were included in these analyses so that they could be included in later regression analyses. Ethnicity was consistently associated with indicators of achievement, whereas gender and parental education were rarely associated with the indicators of achievement. In all instances, identification as Māori or Pasifika was associated with lower achievement scores compared to other students. Having a VIP significantly correlated with 11 of the 13 academic achievement variables, while number of VIPs, VIP education, overall importance of VIP, and frequency of contact with VIP showed few or no significant relationships. VIP warmth was significantly associated with all achievement variables, while parent and peer warmth each were associated with six (out of 13) variables and associations were quite small (all r’s < .20).

caption.p: Correlations Among Indicators of Achievement With Youth Demographics, Parental Warmth, Peer Warmth, and VIP Variables.

fn.p: Note: N = 313; read comp = PAT reading comprehension; vocab-P = PAT vocabulary; word rec = STAR word recognition; sent comp = STAR sentence comprehension; para comp = STAR paragraph comprehension; vocab-S = STAR vocabulary; overall-S = STAR overall raw score; Add & Subtract = asTTle algebra addition & subtraction; Mult & Div = asTTle algebra multiplication & division; geometry = asTTle geometry; statistics = asTTle statistics; VIP = very important nonparental adult; STAR = Supplementary Test of Achievement in Reading; Progressive Achievement Tests; asTTle = Assessment Tools for Teaching and Learning.

sec.p: Due to the large number of indicators of achievement and the similarity among them in their associations to the youths’ demographic variables, parental warmth, peer warmth, and VIP variables, data reduction was deemed appropriate. Using principal components factor analysis with varimax rotation (if required), each cluster of achievement scores (PAT, STAR, or asTTle) were individually assessed. For each group, one component was derived and all items were well above the minimum cutoff of .40. See Table 4 for a summary. Based on these results, overall scores for asTTle and STAR and a mean score for PAT were used in all further analyses.

caption.p: Factor Analyses of Indicators of Achievement.

fn.p: Note: N = 313; START = Supplementary Test of Achievement in Reading; PAT = Progressive Achievement Tests; asTTle = Assessment Tools for Teaching and Learning; VIP = very important nonparental adult.

sec.p: Next, hierarchical regression analyses were run to determine whether VIP warmth made a unique contribution to the overall indicators of achievement; VIP importance and frequency of contact with VIPs were not included in these analyses as they proved to be nonsignificant at the correlational level. It should be noted that only youth who reported having a VIP (62% of the sample) were included in these analyses, as youth without a VIP did not complete the VIP warmth scale. Due to consistently significant associations at the correlational level, ethnicity was included. Hierarchical regression analyses were run on all achievement variables using the following steps: Step 1: ethnicity, Step 2: parental and peer warmth, and Step 3: VIP warmth (Table 5). VIP warmth was a significant predictor of all academic achievement indicators even when accounting for peer and parental warmth and ethnicity. Neither peer warmth nor parental warmth were significant at Step 3; ethnicity remained significant for all three sets of analyses.

caption.p: Regression Analyses for Predictors of Academic Achievement With Three Sources of Warmth and Acceptance.

fn.p: Note: n = 176; START = Supplementary Test of Achievement in Reading; PAT = Progressive Achievement Tests; asTTle = Assessment Tools for Teaching and Learning; VIP = very important nonparental adult.

sec.p: In addition, the regression analyses were rerun substituting presence of VIP (yes or no) in Step 3 for VIP warmth so that all participants, not just those who have a VIP, could be included in the analyses (Table 6). The results were somewhat similar. Parental and peers warmth were not significant at either Step 2 or Step 3 for any of the analyses and ethnicity remained significant in all three analyses. VIP presence was significant in all three analyses, although the Beta’s were smaller than they were for VIP warmth.

caption.p: Regression Analyses for Predictors of Academic Achievement Substituting VIP Presence for VIP Warmth and Understanding.

fn.p: Note: n = 296; START = Supplementary Test of Achievement in Reading; PAT = Progressive Achievement Tests; asTTle = Assessment Tools for Teaching and Learning; VIP = very important nonparental adult.

sec.p: Finally, hierarchical regression analyses were run to see whether the VIP warmth regression effects varied as a function of ethnicity or kin status of the VIP. In addition, overall importance of VIP and frequency of contact with VIP were also tested to ensure that nonsignificant bivariate associations were not resulting from ethnicity and kin-status variables serving as suppressors. To conduct these analyses, interaction terms (VIP warmth, VIP importance, and VIP contact with ethnicity or kin status) were created and added to the regression equation as the final step. For VIP warmth, VIP importance, and VIP contact, none of the interactions with ethnicity or the interactions with kin status were significant for any of the three major indicators of achievement, all p’s > .05 and all ΔR2’s < .02. These nonsignificant findings indicated that the association between VIP warmth and achievement was not moderated by ethnicity or kin status and that VIP importance and frequency of contact with VIP remained nonsignificant.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study examines the association between VIP-adolescent relationships and adolescent academic achievement among low-income, ethnically diverse early adolescents in Auckland, New Zealand. One of the strengths of this study is that academic achievement is measured by standardized tests across a variety of numeracy and literacy domains that were reported by the students’ school. Most studies typically use self-report grades or school-report GPAs, which are subject to potential bias due to differential grading by teachers and inaccuracies of student self-report grades.

The results suggest that VIPs are important resources for youth at risk of low academic achievement. As found with other studies of older adolescents in the United States (e.g., Beam et al., 2002), VIP relationships are normative for younger adolescents as most adolescents in this study (62%) report having at least one VIP. In addition, the quality of the adolescent-VIP relationship was better, on average, as compared to parents or peers, similar to findings from other studies of typical youth (e.g., Beam et al., 2002) and at-risk youth (e.g., youth in foster care; Farruggia et al., 2006). While it is noteworthy that adolescents report greater warmth from VIPs as compared to parents or peers (another group that adolescents “select”), to some degree it is not unexpected given the commonalities between definitions of VIPs and warmth. That said, there was variability in the reported level of warmth as seen by the almost 0.5 point standard deviation on the 4-point scale.

A related issue was the relatively small correlation among the three sources of warmth, despite using the same measures and changing only the response target. By using the same measure, the association was likely due, in part, to common method variance (Podsakoff, MacKenzie, Lee, & Podsakoff, 2003). Interestingly, the parent-VIP correlation was particularly small, even though both represented the quality of relationships with adults in the adolescents’ lives. These small associations may indicate that all youth, even those who report lower-quality parental relationships, are able to develop a positive relationship with VIPs. As it is difficult to tell why the association is small, it warrants further investigation.

Unlike other studies in which VIPs were typically kin half of the time (e.g., Greenberger et al., 1998), VIPs for the adolescents in this study were most often family members (75%). Two noncompeting explanations for this difference are offered. First, the age of the participants for this study was lower as compared to other studies. Consequently, the youth in this study were likely to have a more limited social network from which to select their VIP, as they are unlikely to have the same level of autonomy experienced by older adolescents. Second, a large proportion of the participants were Māori and Pasifika, and most previous research was conducted in the United States, which is a different cultural context. Extended family affiliations are culturally important within both the Māori (Metge, 1995) and Pasifika (Fa’alau, McCreaner, & Watson, 2005) cultural contexts. In addition, family groupings within the Māori context and Pasifika context are often multigenerational and extend beyond the typical European nuclear family (Ka’ai, Moorfield, Reilly, & Mosley, 2004; Pryor, 2006), suggesting regular access to a greater breadth of kin.

In all instances, VIP warmth was a better predictor of academic achievement as compared to peers or parents. This was found at both the correlational level and in the regression analyses that controlled for significant demographic variables and identified the unique contribution of the sources of support. This finding is particularly interesting as previous research has highlighted the importance of positive parent-child relationships for academic achievement (e.g., Sirin & Rogers-Sirin, 2004). Coleman (1987) noted that social capital within the community may counter the erosion in the home and that this provides the opportunity to talk about problems that young people may not be able to discuss with parents. It could be the case that the VIPs are filling an emotional gap, thus giving the youth the “room” to focus on education. In addition, it is important to note that youth select their VIPs but do not select their parents. It seems plausible that youth select VIPs who can support them in areas that their parents may not be able to (e.g., in the academic arena) but will only select those they enjoy being with. These results indicate that VIPs are an important resource, particularly for youth who are at risk of low achievement.

The stronger association with achievement of VIP warmth as compared to peer warmth was also interesting. Previous research on the influence of peers on achievement has clearly found an association (e.g., Veronneau & Dishion, 2011). While influence can be both positive and negative, it has been suggested that the negative influence is often stronger (Bishop et al., 2004). In their review of the literature, Brown and Larson (2009) suggest that the association between friendship quality and adjustment (academic and psychological) can be complex and, therefore, inconsistent. For example, Burk and Laursen (2005) found that middle and early adolescents’ positive features of friendships were less clearly associated with adjustment when compared with negative perceptions, which were associated with lower GPA and poor psychological adjustment. It may be the case that aspects of a high-quality relationship, therefore, may be less influential.

Surprisingly, the associations between frequency of contact with the VIP and level of importance with achievement were largely nonsignificant, despite them both being additional indicators of the quality of the relationship. In terms of the frequency of contact, it may be the case that more contact was needed during the establishment of the relationship, as seen with formal mentoring relationships (Sipe, 1998), but not once the relationship was established, as is the case with VIPs. For level of importance, it may be the case that there was not enough variability in the level of importance, as all VIPs were important. Future research should explore these further.

Another surprising nonsignificant association was between VIP level of education and achievement. In a recent study by Chang and colleagues (Chang et al., 2010), VIP level of education was associated with educational expectations and grades. In the Chang study, the participants were transitioning out of high school, whereas in this study the participants were in intermediate school and, thus, several years younger. It is possible that the level of education of the VIP becomes more important when the adolescent becomes closer to making decisions about higher education.

Unexpectedly, the influence of interaction between VIP warmth and ethnicity on achievement was not significant. One explanation for this finding relates to Coleman’s (1987) suggestion that children living in poverty are least likely to have social and human capital in their families and communities. All of the youth in this sample, by virtue of attending a low decile school, were likely in “need” of the social capital that VIPs can provide. As poverty is a demonstrated mechanism for putting Māori and Pasifika at risk generally (Biddulph et al., 2003; Gilbert, 2005), this risk may be more uniform across all students within the context of a low-income school.

Despite that VIP level of education, frequency of contact with VIP, and importance of the VIP were not associated with achievement, these results do suggest, however, that all VIPs are not the same. While VIP presence was associated with higher achievement compared to not having a VIP, VIP warmth was both significant and had larger beta weights and more total variance explained. This suggests that the quality of the relationship with the VIP may be even more important than the mere presence of a VIP. It is this warmth that may serve as one of the mechanisms of how the relationship helps to promote achievement. Indeed, the resilience literature has identified the caregiver-child relationship as a key system that underlies adaptive processes (e.g., Masten, 2001). It may be the case that VIPs fit into that caregiver-child space. Relatedly, research on formal mentoring relationships highlights the importance of trust, closeness, and establishing a bond in the mentee-mentor relationship (Herrera, Sipe, & McClanahan, 2000; Rhodes, Reddy, Roffman, & Grossman, 2005), and mutuality, trust, and empathy as mechanisms through which development occurs (Rhodes et al., 2005). Indeed, Coleman (1987) suggested that relationships reflecting social capital can take the form of listening to problems, enforcing norms, and participating in activities. All of these characteristics reflect high-quality relationships that reflect “interest, even intrusiveness, of one adult in the activities of someone else’s child” (p. 36).

This study has three main limitations. The first is that the data are cross-sectional and, therefore, causal conclusions cannot be drawn. It is possible that more capable students are able to draw out positive qualities from those around them. However, given the low associations among the three type of warmth, this seems less likely. Future research should, however, look at the nature of the relationship over time to determine the direction of the association between VIP-adolescent relationship quality and adolescent academic achievement. Second, some important characteristics of VIPs and parents, such as level of education, are self-reported. Some participants were unaware of this information, causing them to be treated as missing data in the analyses. Third, although a large percentage of the students in the school participated in the study, it is likely that the sample may be positively biased as the most at-risk youth are less likely to be in school on a given day and are also less likely to have secured parental consent.

In conclusion, VIPs have been found to be an important resource for an at-risk sample of early adolescents. The quality of the VIP-adolescent relationship makes a unique contribution to academic achievement, beyond that of ethnicity and other significant demographic variables. Young people need to be encouraged to develop and maintain these informal relationships, as the benefits are potentially large. In addition, schools should recognize the importance of nonparental adults, not just parents, when making decisions about how to keep young people engaged and achieving.

ack.p: We would like to thank the school leadership, students, teachers, and administrative staff at the intermediate school for their commitment to and support of this project.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Susan P. Farruggia is a senior lecturer in developmental psychology at the University of Auckland. Her research interests include the social contexts of development for youth taking into account culture, family, and important nonparental adults, particularly for vulnerable youth.
Pat Bullen is a lecturer at the University of Auckland. Her research interests include adolescent development with a focus on understanding the factors that promote positive youth development.

Joy Davidson is a research assistant in the School of Teaching, Learning and Development at the University of Auckland. Her research interests include child and youth resiliency, developmental risk and protective factors within an ecological framework, and the effect of poverty and maltreatment on children and youth.
